note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Andrew Barry Moore served as governor of Alabama on the eve of the Civil War. Born on March 7, 1807, in the Spartanburg District of South Carolina. He moved to Perry County, Alabama, in 1826, and initially became a teacher. A short time later, however, he began studying law and in 1833 became a practicing attorney. Almost immediately he pursued public office, serving as the Justice of the Peace for Perry County and then, in 1839, winning a seat in the Alabama House of Representatives as a Democrat.

Moore served in the Alabama legislature until 1846, at which point he returned to his law practice. He remained active in Democratic circles, serving as a presidential elector for Lewis. Cass’s unsuccessful Democratic run for president in 1848. In 1851, Moore received an appointment by to the First Circuit Court. He spent six years on the bench until he was elected governor of Alabama in 1857. As governor, Moore advocated the improvement of state hospitals, including facilities for blind and deaf patients, as well as those with psychiatric conditions He also labored to expand railroad development in Alabama.

Moore was strongly pro-slavery, but a moderate on the sectional conflict during the late 1850s. As calls for disunion grew across the south, Moore believed that separation from the Union was not wise for Alabama. However, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in November 1860, Moore adopted a more radical stance and supported Alabama’s secession convention in early 1861. In preparation for that secession, Moore ordered state military forces to capture U.S. Army facilities around Alabama, particularly those guarding Mobile harbor. He also sent Alabama militia forces to Florida to aid secessionists there seize U.S. installations at Pensacola.

Moore time as governor ended in December 1861. He took an appointment as a special aid to the new governor John Gill Shorter, and continued to support the Confederate war effort by procuring and organizing supplies and soldiers. When the Civil War ended, Moore was arrested by federal authorities and temporarily imprisoned at Fort Pulaski, Georgia. After his release, he returned to Alabama and practiced law. He passed away on April 5, 1873, at the age of 66. Moore was married to Mary Goree and had two children. He is buried in Fairview Cemetery in Marion, Alabama.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Encyclopedia of Alabama)

Located in central Alabama, Perry County was established on December 13, 1819. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)
Located in central Alabama, Bibb County was established February 7, 1818. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)
Located in central Alabama, Autauga County was established on November 21, 1818 from Montgomery County. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in central Alabama, Shelby County was established on February 7, 1818 from Montgomery County in Alabama Territory. When the state of Alabama was created on December 14, 1819, Shelby County became a part of the new state. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in central Alabama, Lowndes County was established on January 20, 1830 from Butler, Dallas, Montgomery, Pike, and Wilcox counties. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Dallas County, Selma was founded under the name Moore’s Bluff in 1815 in what was Monroe County, Mississippi, at the time of founding. It became part of the newly created Montgomery County, Mississippi, on December 5, 1816, which was changed to Alabama territory on March 2, 1817. On February 8, 1818, Moore's Bluff became part of the newly created Dallas County. It was renamed Selma on December 4, 1820, when it was incorporated. Selma became the county seat in 1866. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Lowndes County, Columbus was founded on December 6, 1819 in what was then a "non-county area." When Lowndes County was created on January 30, 1830, Columbus became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
A "person, agency or corporation that will act as a surety and pledge money or property as bail for the appearance of a defendant in court." (Wikipedia)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official who has the legal authority to say that documents are correctly signed or true or to make an oath (= promise) official." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p: ATTORNEY & COUNSELLOR AT LAW, NOTARY PUBLIC & COMMISSIONER,
Will attend to all Law and Collecting business intrusted to to his care in the Counties of Perry, Bibb, Autauga, Shelby, Lowndes and Dallas.

OFFICE -- Corner Broad & Water sts.,
Selma, Dallas County Ala.

Some three weeks Since, I Sent you for guns—orders, a requisition from Gov Moore of this State, for the arrest of one Charles Gaines a fugitive from justice in Columbus Miss—I requested you to Send me back the requisition, but as yet have not recd,, it, you will much oblige and Serve the bondsmen of [?] Gaines by attending to & Sending me & him papers as much is to be lost by delay
